prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Reasons for Protection of Confidential Information

para.paratext: A number of policy reasons have been cited as grounds for protecting confidential business information. The court in Seager v. Copydex Ltd.[1] held that:

The law on this subject … depends on the broad principle of equity that he who has received information in confidence shall not take unfair advantage of it. He must not make use of it to the prejudice of him who gave it without obtaining his consent.

The Institute of Law Research and Reform in Canada held that confidential information ought not to be protected where there is an “over-riding public interest which would defeat the public interest in the protection of the information”.[2]
The U.S. Supreme Court in the Kewanee case said this:
“… the maintenance of standards of commercial ethics and the encouragement of invention are the broadly stated policies behind trade secret law”.[3]

Some would argue that the public interest in access to new information and in employee mobility dictates that information be as free as possible. Continuing progress and thus access to new information are necessary for the development of society as a whole. In addition, there are some new developments, such as cures for diseases, which require full disclosure. There is a grudging acceptance of the patent system as an incentive to create new innovations.
The other view is that there is a need for the protection of confidential business information to lower the costs of self-help remedies for businesses and to punish immoral and unfair conduct:[4]

[T]here is the tacit recognition that many trade secrets play … a significant economic role. If protection were not given, encouragement would be offered to the faithless employee and the industrial spy; knowledge would necessarily be fragmented amongst many employees instead of concentrated in a few, thereby creating inefficiencies and higher costs; the spread of technology through licensing would be discouraged. Conversely, granting protection encourages the investment of resources into acquiring and using socially useful information; the investor will know that, if reasonable means are used to keep secret the information, [it] will be able to recoup [its] investment with relatively little risk from poachers. [Additionally,] given the difficulties of deciding whether any particular subject matter is patentable and of drafting patent specifications in such a way as to withstand court challenges as to validity, there seems every reason to have a discrete body of law existing outside the law of patents covering intellectual discoveries that the inventor wishes to keep secret.[5]

The crucial question is whether the innovator will be able to gain a reward sufficient to repay the costs of the innovation and to profit from taking the risk of expending money, time and effort. The prospect of profit must be great enough to make the scientific or technological risk worth the effort. Natural lags in imitation and contractual and equitable barriers such as restrictive covenants and a good faith obligation may allow those who have created or who own the rights to innovations to generate sufficient profit. There are also non-monetary rewards, such as fame, honour and the desire for knowledge, which have spurred inventors. However, both the focus of information and technological innovation as one of the primary, if not the primary source of wealth, in the late 20th century, and the vast sums which are now often expended to create innovations, have greatly increased the need not only for recognition of an innovation, but also for financial compensation for the vast sums expended to create and develop the new information.
The arguments used to justify granting legal rights for the protection of confidential information can be classified into natural or moral rights, and economic rights.
Seager v. Copydex Ltd., [1967] 1 W.L.R. 923 (C.A.), at p. 931.
